user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of find_boundary:
```c
static int
find_boundary (struct MHD_PostProcessor *pp,
               const char *boundary,
               size_t blen,
               size_t *ioffptr,
               enum PP_State next_state,
               enum PP_State next_dash_state)
{
  char *buf = (char *) &pp[1];
  const char *dash;

  if (pp->buffer_pos < 2 + blen)
  {
    if (pp->buffer_pos == pp->buffer_size)
      pp->state = PP_Error;     /* out of memory */
    /* ++(*ioffptr); */
    return MHD_NO;              /* not enough data */
  }
  if ( (0 != memcmp ("--",
                     buf,
                     2)) ||
       (0 != memcmp (&buf[2],
                     boundary,
                     blen)))
  {
    if (pp->state != PP_Init)
    {
      /* garbage not allowed */
      pp->state = PP_Error;
    }
    else
    {
      /* skip over garbage (RFC 2046, 5.1.1) */
      dash = memchr (buf,
                     '-',
                     pp->buffer_pos);
      if (NULL == dash)
        (*ioffptr) += pp->buffer_pos;         /* skip entire buffer */
      else if (dash == buf)
        (*ioffptr)++;                         /* at least skip one byte */
      else
        (*ioffptr) += (size_t) (dash - buf);  /* skip to first possible boundary */
    }
    return MHD_NO;                            /* expected boundary */
  }
  /* remove boundary from buffer */
  (*ioffptr) += 2 + blen;
  /* next: start with headers */
  pp->skip_rn = RN_Dash;
  pp->state = next_state;
  pp->dash_state = next_dash_state;
  return MHD_YES;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No unreachable code detected in the provided function. All control-flow paths are reachable given different runtime inputs and pp states:
- The initial if (pp->buffer_pos < 2 + blen) can be true (returns MHD_NO) or false (execution continues). Inside it, the nested if (pp->buffer_pos == pp->buffer_size) is also reachable.
- The subsequent boundary-check if (memcmp ... || memcmp ...) can be true (enter garbage-handling or error branches) or false (successful boundary found). Within the true branch, both the pp->state != PP_Init and the else (pp->state == PP_Init) branches are reachable depending on pp->state.
- Inside the garbage-handling else, memchr can return NULL, a pointer equal to buf, or a pointer inside buf, so each of the three adjustments to *ioffptr is reachable.
- The successful-boundary path (updating *ioffptr, setting pp fields, returning MHD_YES) is reachable when the memcmp tests indicate a boundary.
The commented-out ++(*ioffptr); is a comment, not code, and therefore not relevant to Rule 2.1. No statements after return, no impossible conditions or invariant contradictions were found, so there are no obvious unreachable code fragments to investigate.
